last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1284011
>compresses gifs and turns them into crusty mp4s
That's Twitter's fault. Every gif uploaded to Twitter gets automatically converted to mp4, and there is nothing that can be done to get the original file.
gallery-dl just downloads file's as they come. It has no built-in functionality to compress/modify anything.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1283799
Probably every update up to the one that you believe caused the error.

You should also have a Windows recovery USB since there's a chance you could have used this to recover from the suspected update error rather than having to reinstall. Instructions here.

https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/create-a-recovery-drive-abb4691b-5324-6d4a-8766-73fab304c246#WindowsVersion=Windows_10

If you haven't one it already, it might help to run steam and verify or reinstall the games.

last_replies.com:
>>1283799
The microsoft C++ redistributables and .NET Framework, check on google what's the file and version giving the error then go to google and install from microsoft page or just install the latest version of those.
Steam installers should check these requirements and install them if needed, some games do at least. Check that the files for the games are correct too. Right click game -> Properties -> Local files -> Verify local files

threads.com: How should I go about making a seperate home partition on Linux after I've already had my system installed on a partition without one? I've migrated my home across a few systems but always end up fucking up my timestamps or other metadata and would prefer it not happen again if it's preventable. Here is a free desktop background for your trouble

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1283795
Back up your data.
Right now. Back up your data.
Unless you have made zero changes to your files since your last back up or you don't care about losing any changes made since you last back up, back up now.

It's quite safe, it doesn't often fail, but you're screwing around with the partition table and there's a non-zero chance of fucking it up yourself or some error fucking it up.

You can do it in terminal but a lot of Linux distros come with gparted and you might find the gui easier for the partitioning and formatting, whatever file manager you use for the file copying parts, and your favourite gui based text editor to edit fstab

But for the rest of things like the mounting and unmounting the link below has good enough instructions and it's all in terminal which you might prefer.

https://www.howtogeek.com/442101/how-to-move-your-linux-home-directory-to-another-hard-drive/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1283671
you've removed the table with name == niggy2 from the table, but v still has a reference for it, which is why it prints niggy2 (even though its deleted)
lua's iterator pairs doesn't really work the way you think it does. when you remove part of the table, it readjusts the table's indices so it skips the third index.
try having two loops: one removes items from the table, one prints. The behavior will be more like you expect

You are right that the next index gets skipped, but this means that if the next element also has d=false, it will not get removed from the table.
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12394841/safely-remove-items-from-an-array-table-while-iterating

Pressing means iron. If the fabric isn't smooth when you sew it will stay uneven and wrinkly when sewn. Btw whenever they say press there's an iron in the picture.

Mark your fabric means "make marks on your fabric" so you know where to do stuff. Mark it however you like. Dressmaker's/Tailor's chalk exists for a reason but you can use pen or paint or whatever, just harder to see and wash off.

>Why those distances?

Because those are the distances the designer has determined are necessary.

Draw strings are never at the very top edge of a bag or the draw string would rip through and you need some space for the casing. You're going to fold the fraying top edge so that is tucked inside.

A, Fold the loose top edge down a little bit, this makes a smooth new top edge.

B, fold this smooth edge down a bit further. You end up with three layers.

C, sew along the bottom edge that was the smooth top edge made in A. You end up with a tunnel which has the original frayed edge inside. The draw string goes through this.

>>>Most of step 3:
Casing is where the fabric is folded over and sewn so that the new edge isn't loose threads. This casing is also the tunnel for the drawstring, that's why there's a gap mentioned on the side edges for the string to exit.

Put the outside faces of the fabric together since you sew inside then at final stage turn bag inside out to hide seams. It says sew 1 cm in from the edge down the right hand side leaving a gap near the top between the marks you made, sew the bottom edge, then sew up left leaving gap.

Fabric isn't magic, it doesn't sprout legs and run around, it just sits on the sewing machine and table. If you're worried you can pin the fabric in a few places like maybe the top, left, and bottom edges while you sew the right, then remove pins as you go.

Backstitch means left the foot of sewing machine so fabric is free to slide, then sew while sliding the fabric backwards a little along your just sewn line.

>>1283696
>But an entire 11cm+ worth sound ridiculous. Also why the two different lengths, what do I do for those two exactly mark the sides at 13.5 and the middle at 11?

Mark them at the edge and sew as I show in my non MS paint illustration. :) They will make a 13.5-11 = 2.5 cm gap for the drawstring.

The top edge will have to folded in to below the 13.5 cm mark. Using a bit of rough maths, that 13.5 cm distance from the top edge to bottom of the gap becomes halved by folding, so there's only about 6cm from the bottom of gap to the new top edge fold. The gap is is 2.5cm so that top edge fold is only about 3cm from the top of the draw string which makes the "funnel" that same about 3cm which you can see in the last picture with the leaf printed bag. You can shift the gap up if you want but a too small distance to the top of the gap looks stupid and, if you don't have enough stitching and backstitching distance, the bag can tear.

Gotta go. Hope this helps.

I think they best thing to, just do it. You're probably trying to visualise 3d stuff in sewing all at once and getting all confused. Actually following along and figuring out one step at a time is so much easier.

88 fully weighted keys, that's what you wanted to say. As for the cost, you know what's gonna cost you a lot more? Buying a proper digital piano later that renders your inferior keyboard useless. Literally don't get anything but a proper 88-key fully weighted digital piano. Semi-weighted keys suck ass, the action is the most important part of the piano, and you really should not get anything with less than 88 keys, it's limiting. If you have good hardware, you can add whatever sound you want, but of course you want it to sound good.
Get a Roland FP10/FP30X or Yamaha P125 or Kawai ES110. I'd go with Roland, I think that's the one with the best action. These all have speakers too, so you can just turn them on and start playing.

It's very easy to pirate Synthesia, and it's very easy to find midis and tutorials in 2k22.

threads.com: any anime with an art style emphasizing natural landscapes and the country-side

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1283431
About half of them I'd say
Particularly:
Castle in the Sky (a little less so than the others)
My Neighbor Totoro
Kiki's Delivery Service
Only Yesterday (OP's pic)
Pom Poko
Howl's Moving Castle
Arriety
The Wind Rises
All these have the best landscapes in Ghibli movies imo

Nausicaa has inhospitable landscapes; Grave of the Fireflies has countryside scenes, but they're very morose and the movie is overall sad; Princess Mononoke has a few but much of that movie's look is soiled by primitive digital effects; and The Cat Returns has really shoddy looking scenes.

P.A. works has the reputation of being an hidden travel agency because their anime tend to take places in real remote places within Japan and they often take good care of showing the landscape. So give them a try, Nagi no Asukara is the most beautiful anime I've seen when it comes to background art and such, but it's more on the seaside.
